Posts.Content:
If you haven't been diagnosed with breast cancer, a diet rich in soy can be beneficial. Soy contains chemicals that mimic estrogen your body produces, but these proto-estrogens are weaker. Some doctors think that they will bind to any potential estrogen-receptive cancer cells (should a few show up down the line) and not "feed" the cancer like your own bodily produced estrogen would. However, don't take a soy supplement! That's too high of a dose. Try to incorporate things like tofu or soy milk into your diet, instead.
Not sure about
 the hormonal cream, but if you have concerns about
 it and the link to breast cancer, definitely talk to your doctor.
Posts.Title: Questions on Hormonal cream and Breast pain

Posts.Content:
Hi everyone,
I'm hoping to get some advice from either people in a similar situation to me, or someone who has faced a similar diagnosis and gotten through the issues my mother and our family are dealing with.
My mother had a cancerous tumor (approx 1.7 cm in diameter) removed from her left breast in May (no lymph node evidence, though there were some cancerous cells discovered in the lymphatic channels and blood vessels of the breast). She’s since recovered from the surgery and is doing radiation therapy for six weeks. The doctor has also advised her to lose weight to lessen her chances of recurrence. I have been trying to get her to work out with me, to no avail. She tells me that she is scared of the cancer coming back, and “just doesn’t care about
 anything anymore.” When she says things like that, I get really upset and try to reason with her, but I know she’s afraid and depressed.
Anyone who’s had cancer, did you feel like this? If so, how did you deal with those feelings?
Thanks to anyone for any help they can offer!
